docs.snippet: With its towering dome, resplendent columns and sweeping stairs, Belgium's Palace of Justice is sometimes mocked as being too grandiose for this small nation. But if victims of the world's  atrocities have their way, the building's courtrooms may ...
docs.lead_paragraph: With its towering dome, resplendent columns and sweeping stairs, Belgium's Palace of Justice is sometimes mocked as being too grandiose for this small nation. But if victims of the world's atrocities have their way, the building's courtrooms may soon fill up with extraordinary human rights cases from far beyond Belgium's borders. Already, complaints of massacres, torture and other horrors have poured in from Africa, Asia and the Middle East, with law suits filed against more than a dozen past and present foreign leaders. Three new complaints involve Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, linking him to the massacre of Palestine refugees in Lebanon in 1982. Israeli groups have responded by bringing terrorism charges against Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader.
docs.abstract: Belgian law adopted in 1993 and expanded in 1999 allows nation's courts to hear cases of atrocities, including genocide and other crimes against humanity, that happen anwhere in world and does not recognize foreign officials' immunity; consequently, country is receiving flood of cases, leaving some politicans and legal scholars wondering if nation has taken on too much; three new complaints involve Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon, linking him to massacre of Palestinian refugees in Lebanon in 1982; Israeli groups have responded by bringing charges against Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; targets of other lawsuits include Pres Laurent Gbagbo of Ivory Coast, Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Pres Paul Kagame of Rwanda and Pres Fidel Castro of Cuba; photos (M)

headline.main: Human Rights Cases Begin to Flood Into Belgian Courts

docs.snippet: When Ishtaq Ahmad came to Afghanistan last month, he was determined to wage a holy war against the American military.    Mr. Ahmad, by his own account, is a member of the Jaish-e-Muhammad, a Pakistani group that the United States regards as a terr...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Ishtaq Ahmad came to Afghanistan last month, he was determined to wage a holy war against the American military. Mr. Ahmad, by his own account, is a member of the Jaish-e-Muhammad, a Pakistani group that the United States regards as a terrorist organization and that initially claimed responsibility for an attack on the legislature in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir on Oct. 1, then later denied it.
docs.abstract: Recent string of Northern Alliance victories in Afghanistan has produced flood of prisoners, from foreign Islamic warriors to local conscripts who were taken from villages and pressed into service by Taliban; photos; Red Cross has been able to visit only fraction of prisoners estimated in thousands; makeshift jails and poor conditions described (M)

headline.main: One Certainty So Far For Captured Fighters: Conditions Are Awful

docs.snippet: A protest by scores of Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners held at the United States Naval Base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, lost steam today after the American military commander reversed a ban against wearing turbans, which had provoked an outcry.    Of...
docs.lead_paragraph: A protest by scores of Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners held at the United States Naval Base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, lost steam today after the American military commander reversed a ban against wearing turbans, which had provoked an outcry. Of the 300 prisoners at the camp, 73 would not eat breakfast today and 75 turned down lunch, said Maj. Steve Cox of the Marines, a base spokesman. Four prisoners were treated today with intravenous liquids for dehydration, Major Cox said.
docs.abstract: Hunger strike and other protests by Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners at Guantanamo naval base loses steam after US commander Gen Michael Lehnert reverses ban on wearing of turbans (S)

headline.main: A Concession On Turbans Calms Protest In Cuba Camp

docs.snippet: These days, there seems to be only one thing about the park at Abingdon Square that everyone agrees on: the sliver of open space between Hudson Street and Eighth Avenue is not a square, but a triangle. Beyond that, the city's sixth oldest park is ...
docs.lead_paragraph: These days, there seems to be only one thing about the park at Abingdon Square that everyone agrees on: the sliver of open space between Hudson Street and Eighth Avenue is not a square, but a triangle. Beyond that, the city's sixth oldest park is the center of controversy over a proposal to reconfigure the one-fifth-acre space. Designed by George Vellonakis, the Parks Department landscape architect who redesigned City Hall Park in 1999, the proposal entails adding a fountain and replacing the asphalt surface with grass. A bluestone walkway, new lighting and historic benches would be added, and a bronze World War I memorial statue in the center would be moved to a location just outside the fence.
docs.abstract: Controvesy continues over proposal to reconfigure Manhattan's Abingdon Square Park according to design by Parks Department landscape architect George Vellonakis; biggest bone of contention is plan to move World War I bronze memorial to outside of fence; chronology; photo (M)

headline.main: Abingdon Square Park: A Triangle in Controversy

docs.snippet: A small trove of documents released last week throws cold water on the notion that high-minded German scientists tried to slow work on an atomic bomb for the Nazi regime during World War II. But the documents provide no definitive answer to the qu...
docs.lead_paragraph: A small trove of documents released last week throws cold water on the notion that high-minded German scientists tried to slow work on an atomic bomb for the Nazi regime during World War II. But the documents provide no definitive answer to the question of why German physicists, who were among the best in the world, made so little progress on an atomic weapon compared with their counterparts in the United States. The idea that German scientists worried about the morality of atomic war and tried to head off the development of a bomb was given wide currency in ''Copenhagen,'' Michael Frayn's award-winning play, which focuses on a pivotal meeting in September 1941 between Werner Heisenberg, the scientific head of the German nuclear project, and Niels Bohr, his Danish mentor. Both were Nobel laureates and towering figures in 20th-century physics.
docs.abstract: Editorial Observer on recently released documents throwing cold water on notion that 'high-minded' German scientists tried to slow work on atomic bomb for Nazi regime; says puzzle of why German program stalled has several overlapping explanations, including Nazi scorn for 'Jewish physics' and fact that some of best German physicists were Jews driven into exile

headline.main: Editorial Observer; Still a Mystery: Nazi Germany's Atomic Bomb Failure

keywords.name: subject

docs.snippet: An article on Jan. 17 comparing modern antiterrorism efforts with the capture of four Nazi saboteurs in 1942 misstated the location of the Palisades Amusement Park, which the saboteurs had intended to visit. It was in Cliffside Park and Fort Lee, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Jan. 17 comparing modern antiterrorism efforts with the capture of four Nazi saboteurs in 1942 misstated the location of the Palisades Amusement Park, which the saboteurs had intended to visit. It was in Cliffside Park and Fort Lee, N.J., not nearby Palisades Park, N.J.
docs.abstract: Correction of Jan 17 article comparing modern antiterrorism efforts with 1942 capture of four Nazi saboteurs

docs.snippet: President Paul Kagame said that he was not ready to withdraw his troops from Congo and that the foreign diplomats urging him to do so were guilty of ''intellectual laziness'' for not realizing why they were there. Foreign Ministers Jack Straw of B...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Paul Kagame said that he was not ready to withdraw his troops from Congo and that the foreign diplomats urging him to do so were guilty of ''intellectual laziness'' for not realizing why they were there. Foreign Ministers Jack Straw of Britain and Hubert Védrine of France met with Mr. Kagame this week. Mr. Kagame said they had failed to acknowledge the reason that his soldiers were in eastern Congo: because Congo's government has backed Rwandan militants. Rwanda, which has supported rebels in Congo's civil war, is one of five outside countries in the conflict.
docs.abstract: Rwandan Pres Paul Kagame refuses to withdraw his troops from Congo, where they back rebels in Congo's civil war; holds British Sec Jack Straw and French Min Hubert Vedrine, failed to admit, in pressing for withdrawal, that his soldiers are in eastern Congo because Congo's government backs Rwandan militants; photo (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Not Ready To Leave Congo

docs.snippet: An article on Dec. 11 about a military study of Persian Gulf war veterans and Lou Gehrig's disease referred incompletely to the veterans' risk of developing the disease, also known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. The study found that among the n...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Dec. 11 about a military study of Persian Gulf war veterans and Lou Gehrig's disease referred incompletely to the veterans' risk of developing the disease, also known as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. The study found that among the nearly 700,000 soldiers deployed to the gulf between August 1990 and July 1991, the risk of contracting A.L.S. was an average of 6.7 cases per million people per year over the 10 years after the war, not over their lifetimes. Among the 1.8 million who were not deployed, the risk was 3.5 cases per million people over those same years, not over their lifetimes.
docs.abstract: Correction of Dec 11 article on Persian Gulf war vr
docs.section_name: Corrections; Washington; New York and Region

docs.snippet: Calling Yasir Arafat ''the enemy of the entire free world,'' Prime Minister Ariel Sharon declared Israel on Sunday to be in a war. He spoke after a suicide bomber blew himself apart in a restaurant in the seaside city of Haifa, killing at least 14...
docs.lead_paragraph: Calling Yasir Arafat ''the enemy of the entire free world,'' Prime Minister Ariel Sharon declared Israel on Sunday to be in a war. He spoke after a suicide bomber blew himself apart in a restaurant in the seaside city of Haifa, killing at least 14 other people, while Israel was tightening its ring of tanks and rifles around the Palestinian leader. Mr. Sharon has made similarly bellicose statements about Mr. Arafat in the past, but his terse remarks on Sunday night seemed intended to prepare Israel and the world for a major new assault on the West Bank, and possibly for a raid into Mr. Arafat's office itself.
docs.abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon, calling Palestinians leader Yasir Arafat 'enemy of the entire free world,' declares Israel to be at war; issues statement after suicide bomber detonates charge in restaurant in Haifa, killing himself and at least 14 others and as Israel tightens military cordon around Arafat's compound in Ramallah; terse remarks seem aimed at preparing Israel and world for major new assault on West Bank, and possibly Arafat's office itself; Israeli forces take up positions on outskirts of Tulkarm in West Bank; tanks and armored vehicles reportedly advance closer to Bethlehem; enter Palestinian-controlled territory in Qalqilya, northeast of Tel Aviv; Palestinian and other Arab leaders increasingly blame US for Palestinians' predicament, after Pres Bush gave qualified blessing for Israeli assault on Arafat's compound; American diplomacy has remained largely silent since then; Pope John Paul II issues call for cease-fire in Easter Sunday message; group of 40 members of pro-Palestinian group walk through Israeli lines to Arafat's office; most remain inside, apparently intending to act as human shield; cause consternation at top levels of Israeli government; Arab leaders call attack on Arafat's compound as threat to regional stability; photos; maps (M)

headline.main: SHARON SAYS ISRAEL IS IN A WAR AFTER SUICIDE BOMBING KILLS 14; MORE TANKS MOVE IN WEST BANK

docs.snippet: The commander of the Indonesian Army when militias backed by the military rampaged through East Timor nearly three years ago testified today that he was not responsible for what he called the ''incident.''    Gen. Wiranto, the former commander, bl...
docs.lead_paragraph: The commander of the Indonesian Army when militias backed by the military rampaged through East Timor nearly three years ago testified today that he was not responsible for what he called the ''incident.'' Gen. Wiranto, the former commander, blamed the United Nations and the East Timorese police for the deaths of more than 100 people in violence that followed a referendum in which the people of East Timor voted overwhelmingly for independence. An independent commission in Indonesia and a United Nations panel concluded two years ago that the military, which opposed independence, had supported the militias.
docs.abstract: Gen Wiranto, commander of Indonesian Army when militias backed by military rampaged through East Timor three years ago, killing more than 100 people, says he was not responsible for 'the incident'; blames United Nations and East Timorese police for violence that followed referendum in which majority of East Timorese voted for independence; independent commission in Indonesia and UN panel concluded two years ago that military, which opposed independence, supported militias; Wiranto appears as witness, not defendant, at trial on human rights abuses by military in East Timor; five mid-level military officers as well as police officers and civilian leaders are defendants; trial has direct bearing on Indonesia's relations with US, where Congressional restrictions are placed on American aid to Indonesian military because of human rights abuses in East Timor (M)

headline.main: Indonesia General Denies Responsibility for East Timor Killings
